content.webTitle: New digital radio gets a bad reception

fields.headline: New digital radio gets a bad reception
fields.bodyText: Meet the latest digital radio from PURE Digital: a shiny handheld device, no larger than a pack of cards and perhaps slightly lighter, which promises to bring you digital audio choice and clarity on the move. At least that's the billing, but Online's trials this week have seen the performance fall some way short of expectations. The device is simple to use, with a joystick and four buttons as controls. The screen is bright and clear, and it certainly is light. But the key feature - the quality of the sound - is a disappointment. Walking around central London it was near impossible to get a steady signal - vital, given that in the digital radio world, something either works or it doesn't. It sounded great while hooked up to the hi-fi at home: but that's hardly the point with such an ultra-portable device. On this evidence, anyone looking to buy a digital portable radio should try before buying - even if you think you're in an area with a strong digital signal. On sale in May - £169.99
